text: 341ml bottle (thx, Alex M.!). Bottled in January 2015. Three varieties of Dernière Volonté in a row. Pours a slightly hazy deep golden with a white head. Aroma is very fruity with loads of pinot noir notes. Taste is similar, quite dry. I would prefer more sweetness, but it is very good stuff.

341ml bottled 2015-01. Kept in a controlled temperature (14 degree) and light room.Pour clear pale orange with a nice dense white foam.Aroma of brett, wood and sweet fruit.Taste is of Belgian yeast with wooden spirits, brett and notes of bread.Medium to high body and carbonation. Dry with alcohol heat.Long warm wooden spirits, brett and Belgian yeast finish.
Fine solid head and apricot coloured body. Good mix of brett notes on the nose, yeast, tanginess. Nice crisp citrus hoppy flavour and dry finish. Well made, nicely drinkable.

Part of their Dernière Volonté Anthologie 4-pack mixer - Réserve 2015. Pours a hazy golden-orange colour with a creamy warm cap, great retention and loads of lacing. Wow, the Pinot Noir works very well in the nose with the floral aromas of fresh grass and spices. Hints of wood as well. The taste has the hops at first, but balanced with vanilla notes from the oak. Not much of the wine in the flavours though, but what a great aged brew.

Bottle from biere-import. Light hazy gold to orange color. Thin white head. Thin to medium sweetness. Medium bitterness. Finish is long. Aroma and flavour is yeast, citric, hops, malt, spices, grape, vanilla, chocolate. So good!

2015 Vintage
thanks to Owen for sharing

hazy orange color. white head. Sticky head and lacing. 
Nose is red wine, oak, yeast, some funk, apple, and pear. Barrel has really taken over. 
taste is dominated by the barrel. Wine and oak. Lots of bugs. Very funky, apple and pear. Soft bitterness. 
Medium bodied, Prickly feel. Very complex and a lot going on. Highly suggested as more funky at this point and highly interesting.

Bottle. Pours hazy, orange white a frothy, fully-lasting, white head that leaves scant lacing. Aroma of clove, grapes, and spices. Lightly bitter and lightly sour, solid malt backbone, medium body, flavors of orange zest, cloves, leather and bread, appropriate carbonation and a lightly sour/dry bitter finish. Will definitely drink this again.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2016 Amber/orange pour with a smaller white cap. Wine in the aroma, oak, pine resin. Vinous up front, oak, lighter red wine notes, resin, grape, somewhat sweet, yeasty.  Medium body, understated carbonation.  Pair this with a funky cheese platter.
Bottle 15. Clear yellow pour with a white head. Interesting with vinous notes that melt with the hoppy bitterness. Good body and mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy orange without much of a head. Smells of grapefruit and orange, some pale malt, and red wine. Tastes pretty much the same. Red wine permeates a grapefruit and orange hop flavor. The hops are not bright, as you would imagine. A little bit of sweetness with oak and bitterness. Red wine lingers in the aftertaste. Low carbonation. Tastes pretty good, but it might be a struggle to drink a whole bottle.

Hazy dark golden amber body. Huge lasting white head. Aroma of dark fruits, grappe, oak, overall quite vinous. I'm getting some grainy caramely notes. Flavours of dark fruits, grappe, oak. Long bitter finish, oak, grappe, grain. Paly aftertaste. Well balanced, complex and very interesting. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Miam !
Nez hyper frais, légèrement vineux, très porté sur le raisin frais, un faux air de lambic. Notes très poivrées.
Bouche : ultra équilibrée, plutôt légère sans être aqueuse, fine, très agréable ! Le vineux se ressent mais on partirait finalement presque sur un riesling et un côté relativement sec. Un fond vert subsiste mais on perd le caractère houblonné. Vinaigre très légèrement perceptible, juste ce quil faut pour redonner de la pêche, un peu de fraîcheur, un fond acide. Quelques notes agrumes. Un superbe panorama floral.
Finale a priori sèche mais longueur très douce et fruitée.
Vraiment superbe.

5/V/16 - 33cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ home - bottled: I/2015 (2016-511) 
Clear orange beer, irregular yellow head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: very fruity, bit floral, spicy, melons. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: very fruity, bit spicy, sweet touch, soft bitterness. Aftertaste: bit funky, spices, pretty bitter. Decent!
Botle from tderoeck. Many thanks! Nose of red wine, well balanced with the base beer. Light sweet, light tart. Refreshing. Good.
Bottle at tderoeck's place, thanks! Better than the brett one, still why?! Light wine, meh.

Bouteille de 341 mL, version 2015

Couleur : Belle robe dorée, mince couche de mousse indiquant une faible carbonatation, et faible effervescence.

Arôme : Sent laspect vineux et vinaigré du vieillissement en barriques de vin rouge, les levures sauvages et le sucre.

Goût : Ce qui me frappe demblée, cest principalement les levures sauvages, et laspect vinaigré du vin rouge, assez fidèle à larôme en fait. Un peu de sucre en arrière-plan.

Appréciation: Je dois admettre que je mattendais à quelque chose de différent. On retrouve très peu la Dernière Volonté originale. Cest loin dêtre mauvais, pas du tout, mais une version vieillie en fût dune bière devrait, selon moi, être une extension de la bière originale, au lieu dêtre quelque chose de complètement différent.

Où, Quand, Comment : 
Bouteille, dégustée le 9/29/2013. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : dorée. 
Apparence : voilée. 


Arôme :  
Levures fruitées (agrumes, traces dabricots), pain, légèrement boisé vineux, notes de houblon herbeux et floral. 


Goût :  
En entrée de bouche : Goût de levures fruitées (agrumes, faibles notes de fruits tropicaux et de poires)
 Aux petites notes épicées. 
Un léger support malté est également présent avec un goût assez boisé (vineux), un léger goût de pain ainsi que des notes de houblon floral.


En bouche :  

Corps : moyen.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : légèrement huileuse.
Finale : moyenne et un peu sèche, composée dun léger goût de levures fruitées avec un léger goût boisé vineux.

Bottled Jan 2015, drunk 2/20/16.
Apples, grapeskins, light pear and some mushy cereal grains behind it. Not a huge aroma but pretty mellow.
Hazy goldenrod with a small white head that fades to bubbles.
Soft, creamy rather grapey texture with vanilla, wood, nectarine, butter, and gooseberry/cloudberry. Other than the cloudberry thing going on, its very muddled and i have no idea what was intended here. Dont think the barrel did much here but it has been a while since ive had the base beer. But its still pleasant enough

12 oz. bottle thanks to Adam C. Slightly hazy gold, thin head. Aroma a light white grape, oak, and light floral and notes of citrus. 
The flavor is really damn nice. The wine barrel is light but lingers through the sip. Slightly tart with a floral and Yeast is noticeable with a slight alcohol hint. Light floral notes after the sip. Really enjoyed this.

12oz shared by AdamChandler. Thanks, Adam! Pours golden with a noff white head. Aroma is dank, lemony, oak. Flavor is caramel, a bit of lemon, cat piss, oak. A bit of clove spice and mild hint of dark fruits with the oak at the finish.
Poured from bottle thanks AdamChandler hazy orange with a light white head. Aromas of fruit belgian candy and oak. Taste is nice and follows aroma with a nice balanced finish.
Really awesome. Thanks Dominic! Pours a hazy orange with aromas of tropical fruit, Belgian candy, and oak. Similar flavours with a nice oaky dry wine finish. So smooth and delicious.

De couleur orangé/pale. On ressent ici en premier plan le pinot noir, suivi de note fruité (mangue et poire). Une mince mousse beige vient glisser sur la paroi du verre. En bouche, un goût vineux vient sentremêler avec son côté fruité de mangue et dorange. Une finale assez soutenu par sa présence vineuse et sucré! Cheers!

341ml bottle. Hazy orange with a foamy white head. Flavors are bread, oak, grapes, butterscotch, apricot, grapefruit, honey, vanilla and alcohol with earthy and vinous notes. Medium body, moderate carbonation, oily texture.

Des effluves vineuses juste bien dosées en début dolfactif avec une explosion de fruits tels poire, cantaloup et banane confite, avec des accents de vanille, de coriandre et de fleurs en prime. Superbe olfactif. Le liquide se présente doré avec une belle mousse blanche crémeuse qui persiste bien. Les accents vineux reviennent en entrée de bouche mais les fruits sont cependant plus sobres. On dénote également une certaine acidité et une finale fortement herbacée qui traine assez longtemps. Les saveurs perçues sont: vin rouge vinaigré, boisé de barrique (léger), poire, melon au miel, vanille (léger) herbes aromatiques frisant le persil et alcool en finale. Une bière dune complexité remarquable qui séloigne du style de par sa maturation en fût et de par sa texture, mais ô combien délicieuse.

Robe orangée plutôt foncée et trouble avec un mince filet de mousse. Arômes dominés par le pinot noir. Assez vineux, des tanins âcres et poivrés et une touche de vanille. On sent également un dose de fruits en arrière-plan: orange, mangue, citron et ananas. Cest frais, juteux et une touche florale vient couronner le tout. En bouche, cest un mélange superbe dorange, mangue et ananas avec un vin rouge poivrées et sucrées. Ensuite se dévoilent des saveurs de vanille, un peu de bois, du zeste de pamplemousse et une légère astringeance venant des tanins du vin. La finale permet dapprécier longuement le vieillissement un fut de Pinot noir. Texture huileuse et corps moyen. Équilibre des saveurs incroyable. Très belle interprétation de cette bière déjà délicieuse à la base.

Orangée trouble qui voit sa mousse disparaître rapidement en laissant un mince voile. Ça sent, en effet le vin. Il y a aussi une forte présence fruitée; ananas et oranges en particulier. Un genre de punch aux fruits, où lalcool serait juste bien dosé. Le goût, en ce qui me concerne, sans décevoir, nest pas bonifié par la barrique. Une acidité rafraîchissante, du poivre et de lalcool en finale. (Emb. 01-15) (1698-010116)
Belle couleur doree voilee avec une mousse blanche respectable. En bouche cest tres vineux, bois, fruits jaunes et rouges, cereales. Cest bien!

341ml Bottle from 4 pack of all variant bought at Marché Village. Aroma: just enough of presence vanilla, oaky, not too much. We can still smell the Belgian yeast behind all that BA maturation. App: hazy golden orange with medium white head, good retention, awesome lacing. Taste and palate: medium to full body, in mouth its more oaky, more vanilla too, light medium sweetness, creamy, light bitter finish. Overall: good variant. Not a huge fan of too vanilla or oaky stuff but this is well balanced. Kinda big though, rich.

ivorywhite head leaves some lacing. orangeblonde colour. aroma is floral, hibiscus, yoghurt, white sugar. taste like aroma, wood, tanins, but soft, yoghurt, floral with a bitter aftertaste. medium body and carbonation. very nice! bottle 33cl / bd jan-2015
Bottle at Bent Elbow. Big grapey aroma with some spice and floral hops. Super grapey taste with some spice and floral hops (like the aroma). Very nice and very different.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2015 Bière revisitée en compagnie de Ju-Lo au brewpub. Cheers man! Cette bière a, à mon avis, deux qualités que je me dois de souligner. La première est sa majestueuse beauté. La bière dans mon ballon ressemble à une grosse pêche à la tête mousseuse, blanche et collante. Le liquide est orangé et semble lourd dans mon verre lorsque je le fais tournoyer. De longues jambes collantes restent accrochées sur le verre et la mousse y reste également accrochée. Vraiment un look sublime! La deuxième grande qualité de cette bière réside dans le temps de maturation en fût. En effet, je redoutais fortement un liquide lourdement boisé, acide (dû au chêne) et vineux mais ce nétait nullement le cas. Ce vieillissement en barrique de pinot est dune grande subtilité. Est-ce attribuable à une courte période de maturation, ou alors à des fûts ayant servi plus dune fois à y faire vieillir de la bière? Il faudrait interroger le brasseur à ce sujet, mais toujours est-il que mes papilles ont été préservées! Pour le reste, bel agaençement de houblons légers et de malts à peine sucrés sans être secs. Magnifique boulot Jean-François!

Bottle at BD Edinburgh. It pours lightly hazy orange amber with a small white head. The nose is soft, juicy, bready malts, brioche, stewed orange, vinous, gooseberry, earth, kumquat, marmalade, straw and some floral notes. The taste is crisp, bitter, vinous, some warming alcohol up front, grape skin, gooseberry, orange rind, straw, pepper, light lactic bite, earth and some orange marmalade with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Good depth of flavour for sure. Perhaps a touch boozy, but very nice nonetheless.

Bottle at brewdog.. Golden amber.. Thin white lacing.. Soft fruits.. Soft zezty fruits.. Juicy lemon nose... Soft floral fruit.. Zezty lemon fruits.. Juicy fruits... Big soft floral fruit zezty lime fruit
Bottle at Brewdog Edinburgh. Pours hazy orange. Nose is red wine, light sour, wood, fruits. Taste is Vineous, fruits, yeast, oak, grapes. Quite interesting and nice.
Bottle at brewdog Edinburgh. Pours hazy orange, nose is grape, toffee, fruity, taste is juicy, fruity, dry finish.

Bottle, 2013 vintage. Pours a hazy golden beer with a big white head on top. Aroma is vineous, oaky, yeasty, white fruits and a hint of Brett. Flavor is slightly acidic, vineous, tarty with a touch of oak. A bit strange overall, with a light stringent sourness in the aftertaste and also some bitter touches. Hard to place this one, but I rather like it.
12oz bottle pour at Lakehouse for sunday breakfast. Golden orange and cloudy. Ripe peach and grapefruit aroma. Super fruity beer. Flowers and banana. Interesting. Good for the style

Bottle sample from tasting. Pours hazy golden straw color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is an inviting mix of fruits, citrus, spicy yeast, pale malt, oak, vinous character and light floral hops and grass. The flavor begins on a smooth note with lemon zest, yeast, pale malt, plum, vinous notes, oak, tannins, good, not great.

2011 bottle that I cant remember if it was from a trade or not, but if it was thank you very much. Pours a little copperish like. White head that dissapates quickly, but not completely. Nose is a touch sour, and sweet. Tastes immediately of barrell vanilla, then fruit like pear andesite wine grapes. Just great.

bottle from local IGA A: vanilla/coconut, pinnaple/peach, coriander, spicy. app: hazy pale tick white head with excellent lacing t/p: med body with a moderate long bitter finish with a touch of acidity. o: great. the wood adds a great depth /roundness. would definitely buy next year edition.

(2013 bottle at the DDC tap takeover @ barVolo, Aug 23 2014) Pours a deep orange gold with a small white head and no lace. Aroma prominently oaky pinot noir barrel and light Belgian yeast with grapefruit juice. Palate sweetish pale malts, grapefruit flesh, slightly herbal hops, a bit of wood and wine towards the finish, ends dry and herbal with moderate hop bitterness and lingering oak. Mouthfeel average with fairly high carb. The hops have faded a bit as expected but the effect is surprisingly nice, they integrate well with the quite strong barrel character and supporting yeast. Vinous and delicious sipper, better than I expected and better than the base beer.

On tap at Hopfenstark Ho.st. A complete dense opaque honey gold pour with a thick solid milky cream head.
A big thick boozy Pinot noir aroma - solid. Very full bodied, velvety with a huge barrel quality - oaky, vanilla, Pinot noir, tart vinous flavor. Very nice, very tart oaky sour Belgian goodness. This is all about the barrel...

Bottle, pours a nice bright yellow, with a nice head, aroma is floral and some barnyard funk. Taste is very nice, its floral, with some spicy notes, with a nice smooth barrel finish, the barrel is not too strong but just right, really nice stuff

small bottle at home - gift from tommy10101 - thanks! Pours hazy golden yellow with a thin fine mousse head. That nose is. just. incredible. True refined Pinot est(h)ers - makes one think of that other great Pinot Noir barrel aged beer called Supplication: the subtle-est of the forests fruit scents, mixed with the fines peach nose. Medium body with a full fruit profilz and a slight bitter smoky finish. Taste is a tad less subtle than the aroma, on the green bitter side.

341 ml bottle at Bar Hop. Pours a murky, dull golden orange with modest-sized white head. Aroma has nice balance of red wine barrel and Belgian IPA with equal parts vinous and funky yeast notes. Flavour is funky Belgian yeast, citric hops and subtle but readily apparent red grape and barrel character. Carbonation fairly lively. Quite nice.

Crisp golden 1 finger sticky head. Really nice nose. tannic merlot grape, sticky sweet with a very mild bitterness of oak and pine cone. grape skin and apricot. Taste is nice. great bitterness, wine really dominates the taste. its sweet, minor medicinal. Oaky spice finish.

341 mL bottle. Light honey with a splotchy white cap. Nose is pleasently winey, grape, oak, candy floss and spicy hop, citrus peels and juicy fruit gum. Mildly sweet and well bittered. A light body and above average carbonation shows a touch of alcohol. Creamy palate. Very well done.

Finally putting in written reviews Ive forgotten about. Pours a bright orange with a lot of haze. The nose is rather vinous and funky with barrel notes blending well with fruity aromas. A bit sweet in the middle with woody and earthen notes. A bit of citric tartness towards the finish with light hop notes and beautiful Belgian esters. Quite vinous and woody with pervasive funky notes.

341 mL bottle at Volo, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy orange-golden with a small white head that fades to a thin remnant and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose has big white wine notes, along with oak, citrus, herbs, yeast and subtle hops. The flavour is balanced, moderately sweet with honey and pale malts, herbal notes and subtle floral and citric hops. There is also a hint of tartness from the wine barrel. The finish is long, moderately sweet with citric notes, along with white wine notes and subtle oak. On the palate it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall this is a very nice wine barrel aged blond ale. A very harmonious blend of flavours. 2013-07-15

Orangée et légèrement trouble, une épaisse mousse blanche telle un champ de coton trône au sommet du liquide et refuse de partir. Un nez subtil mais invitant dépices, de levure et dorange ne laissent pas présager un aspect vineux au goût. Pourtant, ce caractère vineux prend une place de plus en plus importante au fur et à mesure que la bière se réchauffe. Elle devient alors un peu acétique, sans toutefois effacer les saveurs primaires de la Dernière Volonté, soit les céréales et lorange. Une amélioration intéressante à une bière déjà solide à la base.

Bottle: Thanks to Pushkinwow: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Small to medium sized creamy off white foamy head on top of a hazy yellow orange colored beer.
Aromas of oak, brett, flowers, some grapes and light hints of yellow orange fruit, light light dusty (yeast), light vinous.
Subliminal mix of wood, brett and flowers. Awesome and serious love!
Flavours of brett, wood, oak, fruits, light bitter, lighter sweet as in vinous, grapes, some chalk, flowers.
Aftertaste is woody, light chalky, some yeast, fruits and bitters. Not lingering but smooth and balanced!
Low carbo, creamy close to silky mouthfeel, smooth medium to full bodied and a creamy thicker texture.
Such an awesome aroma, so easy to drink, this is seriously a subliminal beer! Amazing!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Aroma:red wine cherry,mixed with belgian yeast..
Appearance:Hazy orange good white head..
Flavor:woody,fruity yeast,hoppy..I think is a plus for this beer to put in a oak of pinot noir. nothing more very interesting...But its ok..
Bouteille 341 mL. Edition de 2011 embouteillée en 2012. Nez de pomme, de chene, de cereales et un peu de brett. Un peu plus de brett en bouche, finale astringente. Belle presence en bouche.

Bottle - thanks Sebastien! Pours cloudy orange with a small creamy off-white head that dissipates slowly with nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is very vinous, red wine, honey, lactic tartness, wood, lemon. Flavor is the same, oaky and vinous, light sweet, just a bit of tartness. Lemon zesty bitterness on the finish. Medium body but very smooth in the mouth. Finishes dry.

Bière orangée, trouble, peu mousseuse. Le nez est fruité, vineux, subtilement boisé. En bouche, la première volonté de cette Dernière Volonté est de nous présenter lamertume de ses houblons, celle-ci étant soutenue par une certaine sucrosité, le tout étant agrémenté par les saveurs boisées et les arômes de pinot noir. Au premier abord, laccord semble manquer de naturel... mais après quelques lampées, on en redemande. En bout de ligne, 341 ml, cest le seul vrai défaut de cette bière!
Jadore le résultat du vieillissement en fût de pinot!! Cest audacieux mais très réussi. La mousse tient peu mais bon...

En fût au 15e anniversaire/Zwanze Day de DDC. Couleur or trouble, mousse blanche laissant une dentelle éparse. Arôme floral, agrumes, raisin? Goût doranges, floral, légère amertume, boisé en fin de bouche. Carbonation moyenne, corps moyen.

355 ml bottle received in trade and shared in the CBC2013 line to get in. Thank you pushkinwow! Recreated rating since I lost my original one :(. Pours very hazy orange with a frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some nice looking lacing on our plastic cups. Smell is fruity, vinous and tannic with crackers, white bread, phenolic yeast, white grapes, moist wood, moist soil, hay, white pepper corns, coriander, apricots, mango, grapefruit juice, lemon zest, overripe gooseberries and Chardonnay wine. Taste is slightly bitter, fruity, tannic and tiny herbal with crackers, white bread, grass, moist wood, dark grapes, white grapes, plums, hay, grapefruit juice, mango, starfruit, apricots, lemon zest and white pepper corns. Mouthfeel is round, slightly dry, soft and medium bodied. Finish is tiny bitter and tiny sour with crackers, white bread, white grapes, grapefruit juice, hay, moist wood, white wine, apricots and mango. Very tasty and a perfect start to the CBC weekend.

Bottle - Apricot, honey, grains and yeast. Cloudy orange with a decent white head. Oak, grape, apricot and a pleasant acidity/sourness that finishes with more of the barrel notes. Very different than the regular, but much more complex and interesting.

what an awesome tick from glouglouburp. you simply do not see ticks like this every single day unless you are some kind of basement deity or have easy access to CIB. what a chill day to drink a belgium ale. Pours a golden orange with a soft small soap bubble head. aroma presents deep melon, pear skin, faded old wet oak, hint of red wine. fruity. fine. some oxidation. taste is pleasant bright wet oak, lemongrass, rustic spruce herbs. hint of candied sugar, bubblegum. touch of dry resin. neat. dry enough. nice body. taste better than aroma where i am @. canada lifts.
Clear golden orange. Aroma is fruity red wine, honey, spicy. Taste is a light fruity, strong wine flavours, fantastic balance, quite sweet, but very light and easy drinkability. Outstanding beer.

Tap at the BarHop tap takeover. Pale golden - light orange. Nose is very vineous and peppery. A touch of fruit and some light lemon as well. Lean bodied and slightly tart. A bit of fruit and some definite grape character. Light barrel astringency. Lovely really. Fruity and fresh.
Trade from a ratebeerian - this aged in oak belgian is a great reminder of what well crafted beer can be.

341 ml bottle, 2011 special reserve (thanks, czar!). Pours a cloudy golden with a resilient white head that leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is wine and tartness. Flavor is yeast, pear, sweetbread, dusty and oldish brett funk. Finish is some red wine, spices and a bit of floral bitterness. Lingering flavor of dry, dusty, old barnyard. Strong body, sticky mouthfeel, weak carbonation. As heavy and flavorful as it is, it succeeds in retaining some delicateness. A beer fit for a great occasion.

Bottle @ Bar Volo. Pours hazy pale golden amber with a small lacing off white head. Aroma is acidy vinous yeasty spicy a bit stable fruity. Flavor is refreshing astringent sourish vinous stable fruity medium bitter malty finishing with a longlived astringent bitter vinous aftertaste.

[thanks, Cyrus!]
Aroma is sort of lambic-esque,with vinous red wine and butterscotchy oak. Hazy dark yellow under an epemeral thin, white cover. Smooth, sweet base malt flavour that seems delicate yet not overpowered by the oak and wine accents that are clearly present. A well balanced beer that makes excellent use of the wine barrel to highlight the balt and Belgian yeast characteristics of the fermentation. Medium body, moderate carbonation, faintly sour wine finish.

341 ml bottle thanks Pat! Pours a nice cloudy golden haze with very little head that quickly disappears. Smells fantastic notes of sourness from the wine and some Belgian yeast. Taste is fairly carbonated, not picking up much here, is very crisp with little fllavour and has a very dry finish with a bit of sourness. Interesting beer and I enjoyed trying it.

Bottle while waiting for CBC 2013. Thanks to _angst_. Cloudy apricot color with a nice lasting white head. Fruity vinous aroma, apricots, pear, woody, yeasty notes, spicy, mango, citrus, floral notes. Fruity floral flavor, vinous, yeasty, hoppy, grassy, sourish, woody notes.
Soft nose with obvious white wine characteristics. Fruity and spritzy - peach, some honey and chardonnay. Smooth body, well rounded by the barrel. Unique.
Bottled. Nose of oak, butter, peaches, Chardonney, then pinot, but wine definitely, and orange. Dry, oaky flavor, a bit butter. Dry as hell. Interesting but a bit off-putting.

Bottle at tasting, thanks Tim. Orange, bit hazy, white bubbly head. Aroma is funky, cream cheese and chive, lots of funk. Taste is nice, bit sharp, quite fruity, lots of grapes, flat creaminess. Nice winey backbone. Like it a lot.

Thanks goes to Mike for not raping me in the alley and presenting me with this beer instead. 10 minute power review begins...... NOW!! Hazy apricot, small head due to an unusually careful pour, thin silty lacing. Perplexing nose: similar BA finish with similar notes hitch hiking into the bottle as the 6e. Strong oak, berries (substituting in strawberry), honey. Apricot, straw, dull pepper. The aroma lacks power but has some delicate qualities. Flappy mouth thing of wonder: sweet berries, misplaced yet acceptable sourness, apricot, dryness, belg yeast, pepper is more obvious in taste than in snort but still subdued. Lemony tartness, light funk I think. Ok mouthfeel - its all over the place so I guess that is cool. My only honest sips for pure enjoyment only half intrigue me. Lots if stuff going on but it doesnt quite get put all together in the flavour category. Not your normal beer tho. Ankles.

I think my friends analogy of a sophisticated women with a certain something  to her that cant be pinpointed is a good analogy of the beer. Smooth, round deep and complex. Very nice from start to finish. Oak is more noticeable than pinot noir.

Bottle shared by Drew. Thanks! Pours a straw gold, lightly hazed. Nose is full of white wine, soft oak, a bit catty. Faint yeast and straw. On tasting, light tart white wine. Some oak tannin to build this out. Light tart notes dry out the palate. This took to the barrel very well. Quite nice.
Bottle. Pours hazy gold with white head. Aroma oaky, pluots, tankic, flavors pluots, oaky, tannic, bit watery but good.

12oz bottle. Thanks to Andrew for sharing this... Pours a slightly hazy pale orangey hue and topped with a thin wispy white head... Aroma of earth, oak, light citrus, vanilla, and a touch of yeast. Miley sweet, a touch tart... Flavors are more of the same with light buttery yeast and mild oak. Slightly tart and tannic and sweeter through the middle. Slightly dry backend and thinner bodied.

2011 Pinot bottle via a trade. Pours with a murky orange-golden hued body with a ring of white head. Aromas show lots of wet wood, oak, red wine, berries, slightly musty, baked bread, vanilla, jammy. Slightly chewy. Flavors are of marmalade, jammy, wet wood, pinot, dry, tea, millet bread, deep caramel, light spice. Medium bubbles, dry and tannic. Light nougat. Elegant.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Bottle from a gift pack. I previously tasted it on tap too at our local beer fest. Pours a nice and slightly hazy golden, with a well behaved head that sticks to the sides of the glass. Aroma is winey with fruits and a bit of dirt. Unidentified hops make a muted appearance too. Taste is not that bitter really, with a nice white wine-ish acidity. Mouthfeel is nice with an appropriate carbonation level (low-medium). Im afraid to be sick with homerism, but it is really that good! I only wish it would be more available!!

On tap at Dieu du Ciel in St-Jérome. The color is ahazy honey with a thin beige head.The aroma is of hops and citrus fruits.The taste  some of the same plus a touch of malt and  yeast .The pinot noir effect is not that strong.The aftertaste is very pleasant and refreshing.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2014 Bottle 341ml. Thx alot Czar.
Pours pale golden with medium white head. Good lacing.. Aroma is of malt, fruits, wine. Taste is about the same. Very strong wine notes. Overall: Very good and complex. I had this one multiple times, and have always enjoyed it. This is in my humble opinion one of the best by Dieu du ciel. That barrel aging really improves this beer. Reminiscent of zindandel barrel action.

...I think it would have improved with age.  Its got a lot of body, and pretty sweet, but very little character from the pinot.  Lots of oak but no wine, and the palate is sort of flat.  Its a pretty decent belgian ale, but given the barrel aging I was looking for something more complex.
Version plus vineuse et moins épicée que loriginale, les houblons brillent un peu moins également. Ça reste un breuvage intéressant.

341mL bottle at the Dieu du Ciel 14th anniversary party, pours a cloudy golden orange with almost no head. Aroma is huge on the red wine barrels, some white and red grapes, and a bit of yeast. Flavour tastes as if its been aged in both white and red wine barrels, lots of vinous oak character dominating the flavour  not much, if any, of the original hoppy Belgian character left. Very vinous. Very enjoyable, though I prefer the original.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of BMan1113VR)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a medium white head.  Aroma of vanilla, oak, grapefruit peel, orange, pear, and caramel.  Flavor of orange, vanilla, oak, earth,  and vinous with a dry finish.
UPDATED: SEP 14, 2012 From the tap poured an amber color with a small amount of head.  Light malty sweet flavor with a quick finish.
Pours hazy yellow with white head.  Citrus scent.  Somewhat sweet citrus flavors with hoppy finish.  Cereal and malt notes.  Slightly hoppy finish with sweetness.

Another FANTASTIC beer by DDC.  The base beer is brought to life with lively barrel characteristics and a funky very lightly tartness.  The spicyness of the barrel and the vinous wine characteristics all add to an amazing beer.

Sample on tap at Festibière (Quebec City). Pours hazy amber with tiny off white head. Aroma: strong notes of wine, plus wood, yeast, malts and fruits. The wine taste is very present and quite pleasant. Excellent beer!
Ok this is awesome. Ill bet this one is Oregon Pinot noir. Vanilla oak characteristics
Draft.  Medium off-white head, murky amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grape, wood.  Taste is moderately sweet, wood, grape, some light funk.  Fairly smooth medium body.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2016 Bouteille 341 ml achetée chez DDC St-Jérôme. 7%. Couleur jaune assez foncé, un peu brouillée, mousse blanche. Au nez, arôme de vin et chêne assez présent...suivi de malt et levures. En bouche, douce, très douce, on peut goûter tout le chêne ainsi que des notes de Pinot, le houblon sensuit. Cette version laisse peu de place aux agrumes et à la levure.... un peu en finale..avant lamertume et même un peu dastringence. Excellente version.

This pinot version was on tap at the brewpub.  Hazy tan with thin head.  Vinous and woody with light pale malts.  Light tartness, again with pale maltiness.  Decent flavours, honestly nothing innovative but good stuff.
Draft at armsby abbey, rose orange color. Rose petals, red wine notes. Very floral. Fruity yeast. Like this

On tap at DDC 
Aroma  sweet with hop side, slight pepper feel. Gentle cask elements. Mild alcohol wrap.
 Appearance   poured as milky hazed amber. Beige light top. Rings of lace on glass. 4-
Flavor and Palate : medium bodied. mellow with mild carbonation. Hop play with cask hints. Balanced theme. Finishing bitter with mild sournes.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ - cloudy blond-orange beer with a persistent foam; very woody, citrusy hoppiness and notes of pine and raisins; pretty sweet and full-bodied; residual sugars; very fruity estery and woody finish

pours hazy bright golden with a relatively small white cap, some retention. pinot noir (yes) notes, light tropicalness, lemon, tart fruits. big grassy hops. slightly fizzy yet soft carbonation, oily body, medium to long grassy and grapefruity finish, very dry finish.

341ml  bottle from BlogueDeBieres. Pale somewhat hazy yellow with a white head. Up front vinous and oak notes with some light brett, lemon, green apples - quite light but alcohol is present. Smooth, moderate carbonation, full bodied, very fruity and delicious. Becomes very dry, takes on a somewhat chardonnay character at the end.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2012 2012/21/04: Tap at Soirée des Grands Crus, Siboire (Sherbrooke). Appearance: Cloudy golden/blond with a medium white head. Beautiful lacing. Aroma: Strong fruits notes, herbal/floral, brett. Taste: Loads of fruits, red wine, wood (oak) citrus. Vinous and slight tartness. Overall: Wow! So different from the regular one. Very complex and perfect balance. Refreshing and high drinkability. Astonishing product from DDC! [4/9/9/4/18 = 4.4]

2012/07/25: Bottle (341 ml). Clear orange/golden with no head. Aroma of wine, belgian yeast and fruits. Taste of wine, fruits, belgian yeast with slight wood notes. Mouthfeel is winey/acidic. Medium body. Different from the regular Dernière Volonté but less than draft version. Its still a solid beer, but the draft version was way better. (8/3/8/3/16 = 3.8)
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2012 Bottle thanks to Dany. Pours gold with white head. Nose/taste of vinous notes, yeast, lemon funk and grass. Medium body.

8/22/11 dieu du ciel volonte aged in pinot barrels.

lemony yellow with a white head. hazy? 4

a is lemon peel, lactic, woody, earthy, funky stuff... ie jolly pumpkinish, slate, cheese, florals, a little rubber/medicinal, honey.

f is the same...really interesting. 
crisp, really dry and a great pairing to roasted pork.

Bottle shared at RBWG and another from Savvy1982 via trade -- thanks, Kyle!  Pours golden in color with a substantial white head.  Loaded with...everything.  If you said the word out loud, you would probably start tasting it in this beer.  Its like a mood ring!  Notes of apple skins, tannins, flowers, cheese, and caramel are all present in the aroma and flavor.  A great balance of sour and sweet.  The depth is pretty amazing.

12 ounce bottle thanks to Dany! Pours a somewhat clear golden color with a large white head. The aroma is awesome funky and woody Brett and vinous notes. The flavor is more mellow with noticeable tart and vinous notes, dry, apples, a rich blonde ale.

bottle thanks to Alex... dark peach with a light off white head... smells outstanding, tons of sweet smooth white wine with a little oak, Im vexed as to how this was aged with a red wine... the taste is a bit boring, light yeast with a bit of lemons, the finish is very dry, ok but didnt live up to the nose

bottle during RBWG-hazy yellow huge with a small fluffy white head.  crazy nose-butterscotch, green apples, sharp cheese, vineous, estery (flowers and lemon) with lite alcohol (probably from the barrel-booze)-these notes all show up in the flavors with an added sourness, especially on the finish.  very tasty and really unique twist on this style.  i will probably never be able to have this beer again so im glad i had this sample!

enjoyed during 2011 RBWG thanks Kyle!  Pours light brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is butterscotch and grape skins.  Flavor is tart apple, mild vinous notes of juicy green grape and oak, ends mildly tart with a dry yeast funk

Bottle generously shared during AZRBWG. Pour is hazy gold with a white head.  Aroma shows notes of butterscotch, greeny apple skins, honey, and light wine notes.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of oak, vanilla, citrus, and white pepper.

Bottle at RBWG. Pours hazy gold, thin off-white head, spotty lacing. Nose is spicy, creamy butterscotch, nice spicy hop notes throughout; grape notes are present, if muted. Flavours of butterscotch, cream, floral finish. Lovely stuff.
Cloudy gold, wispy light head.  Aroma is spice, light oak, light red wine notes, yeast.  Flavor is yeasty, malty, vinous, lightly tart flavor, fluffy mouthfeel. Yes!

12 oz. bottle via Brandon; 2009 reserve; cloudy light gold with thin white head; peppery lemons, dry malt; lots of pepper, dry spice; tangy, spice and sweet mix; not quite my thing; harsh spice and bite going down

February 2010 - 341ml bottle shared by blankboy with me and garthicus.  Cloudy deep yellow with a big frothy white head.  Sweet grainy malt aroma with buttery oak/vanilla resin overlaid gently with hints of lemon and fresh-cut hay.  Tastes - whoo-wee! wine!! - definitely vinous, with strong dusty/dry oak tannins, that characteristic sharp Belgian yeast and quite a bit of pungent grassiness - really bold, and the alcohol asserts itself too.  Somewhat thin of body, but strongly carbonated, finishes a bit dry and oaky - really, really nice stuff.

Bottled; wish I could remember who sent this to me, but thanks whoever it was. Pours a mostly cloudy golden with a mild head. Raw, unctuous, slightly salty nose, with ripe red berry, marjoram, peaceful oak. Moderately sweet, with a pronounced, impressionable yeast. Warm, round, oaky body, mild citrus and caramel undertones. Excellent complexity, nice balance.
thanks bvc! golden yellow, slight hazy body. nice gentle subtle fruity nose balanced with oak. nectar up front, dry cottony middle, spicy peppery finish, light bodied throughout

Bouteille de 341 ml, dégustée côte à côte avec la régulière et en compagnie de Slovak Sniper, quelle belle soirée !!. Millésime 2009. Bière blonde avec une belle mousse blanche. Peu de différence avec la régulière. Des arômes fruités se dégagent, petite acidité perceptible. En bouche le bois et le vin agrémente le tout, les saveurs sont complétement différente. Lacidité du vin est perceptible et agréable, bonne acidité.

(Courtoisie de papat444, bouteille de 341 ml, vintage 2009.  Dégusté avec rodenbach99)  Le liquide a une teinte blonde et est légèrement voilé.  Une tête mousseuse blanche résiste quelque peu.  Le nez et le goût sont marqués par le vieillissement en barrique de pinot noir : des effluves boisés assez forts se combinent avec des parfums et des saveurs de raisins, de pomme verte et de levure.  Présence dun aspect floral.  En bouche, le liquide est de moyenne corpulence avec une effervescence qui répond au style et une texture légèrement râpeuse.  En finale, quelque chose qui me rappelle le vin blanc très sec avec une amertume proprement belge et quelques touches dun cidre acidulé et astringent.
Great aroma - subtle yet quite complex aroma with the yeasty notes of the base beer playing off the vinousness of the pinot noir barrel.  The flavor, though, ends pretty dry and rather astringent.

In short: A fruity and very woody dry belgian blonde ale.  Original beer.
How: Bottle 341ml.  A few times.  This rating for a bottle consumed about 6 months after the beer release
The look: Cloudy golden-blonde body topped by a small off-white head
In long: Nose of fruit salad and wood shop.  Taste is a two phases thing.  First is a sweet fruity attack with white grapes and a lot of dried light color fruits.  And then a strong wood dryness take over.  Very woody.  The wood here has a woodshop (like 2x4 construction wood) character.  A little sawdust in the finish.  Alcohol is not well hidden and feels more than 7.5%.  None of the mega-aromatic hops of the regular version.  This beer is aged in wine barrels but I did not find it vinous at all.  Not even juicy.  Some grapes flavour maybe, but thats it.  This is totally different from the regular Dernière Volonté.  I much prefer the regular version but this barrel aged version is so different that it does not feel like a bad Dernière Volonté.  Its just a nice beer on its own.  Overall I think I preferred the beer scene before this Barrel Aging everything trend.  Maybe I am just very old fashion.  Id like to be buried in a Pyramid.

A hazed golden ale with a thick lacing off white head. In aroma, a nice fruity wooden laden malt with some light Brett action. In mouth, a smooth belgian inspired ale with notes of wood, orval yeast, crisp and smooth. 12 on. bottle from DDC in St. Jerome.

Bottle, 341 ml, gift from Philippe Wouters, savoured on February 7 2010; eye: golden, clear, tiny white head, no effervescence; nose: oak buries everything; mouth: oak buries everything, finale in oak, full body, good carbonation; overall: disappointing

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille, 341 ml, cadeau de Philippe Wouters, savourée le 19 janvier 2010; il : dorée, claire, petite mousse blanche, pas deffervescence; nez : chêne enterre tout; bouche : chêne enterre tout, finale en chêne, corsée, bonne carbonatation; en résumé : déçu

[2877-20100521] 341mL bottle. Candy wood oak aroma has nice red wine barrel characteristics with sweet vanilla hints. Slightly hazy, light brown orange body with a quick foamy white head. Mango pineapple wood barrel flavour has some mild red wine barrel notes. Medium body. Interesting! Melded surprisingly well.
(Vintage 2009; c/o Bobsy, w/ him, jerc, Julie)

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Vin. Pours a sick, deep, turbid murky orange blond with a thick, pillowy, fluffy white head with monstrous lacing. Aroma of sweet Belgian candied sugar, buttery biscuit, apples, honey, peaches, nectar, and lavender. Medium bodied with a smooth, doughy, slightly spicy mouthfeel. Finishes clean, dry, and a bit champagne-like. Very good Belgian blonde ale.

Bouteille de 341 ml dégustée avec MartinT et Fred82. Arôme: Odeur de boisé avec une pointe dhoublons et dalcool. Apparence: La couleur est blonde dorée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de boisé avec une pointe de raisins. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de levure en arrière goût. (Rating #3039)

Courtesy of after4ever. Pours hazy grapefruit with off white head. The aroma is somewhat tart and pear and apricot sweet. The taste starts smooth and sweet with malts, graininess, apricots and pears. It then begins to pick up notes of tart apple and a mild drying from the barrel booze notes.

2010-05-21. Crisp dark yellow body with a modest white head. Aroma has a strong oak barrel character, notes of vanilla, touch of white wine and fruity notes that could be from the barrel or the underlying beer. Mild pale malts lay below. 7+ Flavour is similar, oak throughout, vanilla is there but more mildly than in the aroma. Oak is less assertive and aggressive in the flavour than I would have expected - to its benefit. Light fruity character and mild pale malts, light bitterness. Smooth medium bodied palate. 3+ Very interesting. The oak barrel tends to dominate but in a way that works better with the base beer than is the case for some other oak aged beers.  2009 Vintage Bottle shared by Bobsy

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2016 My Bottom Line:
Wooden greenness, distinct vinosity, grape fruitiness and herbal hop bitterness merge in this personable Barrel-Aged Belgian-style Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A circle of foam laces around the misty golden.
-The barrel presence is quite forceful in the aroma and finish.
-The grape character is a perfect match to this beers esters.
-At this point (a few months after its initial release), the hops are overshadowed by the wine barrel, which is a shame, imho.
-Carbonation could be higher and/or more airy to help make the texture more comfortable.
-I much prefer the regular Dernière Volonté, but I appreciate the experience of these barrel-aged batches greatly.

Bottles.

Small medium yellowish head over fully hazy orange beer. Smokey, spicy and fruity nose, old barrels, but very subtle altogether. All the same from above, with an extra bitterish-spicy dimension. Bitterish fruit. Medium bodied, fruitslickness, if that rhimes to something; aftertaste is truly liqueurish-vinous. Another excellent DdC! product;  grand merci à Dany!

341ml bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow-bordering-on-orange colour; the kind of look Id associate with a good wit. The head is bright white and leaves nice lacing. Lots of fruit on the nose, most notably peach, lots of peach. The fruit follows through in the mouth with a little acidic wine twang that balances off the sugar. A rare and interesting treat, but maybe not as good as the original.

Nose of pinot noir grapey notes - light winey fruitiness plus soft belgian ale notes. Fruity, light sweet. Pale yellow golden, nice creamy head and retention. Dusty yeast, lemon, winey notes. Soft fruity yeast. Light tart barrel. Soft carbonation. Smooth winey nice take to barrel.

12 oz. thanks dany! pours a cloudy dark orange. loose tan head. rich yeasty spice and floral grassy notes on the nose. creamy medium body with some lively carb. grassy, wet hay, spice, and perfume on the mid palate. long peppery finish. delicious.

Hazy orange pour, fluffy sticky head. Oak, funky lamic like aroma. The hops are still very present but the barrell really added some great oaky funk! Flavour is quite tangy and vinuous, with more great funk. Very interesting! The Pinot barrel really did some interesting stuff.

12oz bottle pours a hazy, yellow orange with very little cloudy white head.  Aroma is a little cheesy, sweet, good blonde aroma background.  Someone mentioned some diacetyl, a little wood in the nose too.  Flavor is sweet, cheesy, tart, flowers, light lemons, white grapes.  The barrel is definitely absent in the flavor.  Sweet finish, medium bodied, smooth.

Bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thank you sir.  Clear golden color, edge head, scant lacing.  Aroma is bitter, if thats possible.  Taste is balanced bitter/malt, some licorice, some oak, some cedar.  Nice.
Nice white wine nose, good bit of oak. Taste is lightly sweet, very lightly bitter, very vinous, herbal, lots of oak on the finish. Just a touch of oxidation.

341mL courtesy of CaptainCougar. Pours a clear yellow/hazy beautiful orange with the yeast. Decent white head that leaves nice spotty lace. Awesome aroma of Pinot Noir, massive barrel presence, loads of sweet fruits, sweat, funk, buttery notes. Taste is relatively plain: Belgian single with light yeast character, doughy malts, spices. Dry aftertaste.

Bottle. Beer seems to glow as if it is neon golden amber. Thin head. Soft melon and citrus aroma. Beer flavour seems mellowed by the oak aging with stronger alcohol and melon. Aftertaste carries some of the hop bite of the original. An interesting change, a slower sipper but for joy measurement I prefer the original.

341ml bottle purchased at the brewery, cloudy honey gold hue, with a thick white head, mild yeasty, fruity, faint winey nose, with some ripe apple, pear, lychee esters, with a light honeyed pale, toasted malt note and with a hint of vanilla oakiness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a smooth, yeasty, fruity, oaky, woody, burnt barrel, vanilla, winey character, with some tannic, red wine dryness flavors, and a flowery hop leafy bitterness accent, leading towards an alcoholic, hop leafy, light oaky, woody, fruity, winey dry finish.

My bottle [341ml] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o JulienHuxley. Pours a hazy golden-orange with a small frothy white head. Aroma of yeast, fruity wine, some light barrel-aged notes and pale malt. Flavour has a big hit of red wine upfront and slightly more barrel-aged notes to it, the rest follows the aroma. Alcohols well hidden. Medium bodied. Great stuff, a nice rare treat -- Thanks Julien!
Bouteille achetée à la brasserie. Fin col. Le pinot noir ressort vraiment au nez (Et au goût).  Superbe amertume en finale bien balancée avec le vin.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2013 The wood used was of a special nature.  It brings out both subtle and interesting nuances in the beer, not your typical American oak job.  A darker yellow with a significant white head.  Wine, sourish and winey flavours.  Above average mouthfeel. Not everyones flavours, but very rich and good. 3.3 years later on tap at Bar Hop.  Well integrated, not so sour.

Thanks to Blankboy for sharing with HogTownHarry and I. Appearance: Cloudy orange - grapefruit with a small white head. Aroma: Definitely wine in the nose, citrus, oak, grapefruit skin and a little alcohol. Flavour: Wow, definitely wine barrels! Quite a sharp red wine flavour with oak, malt, hops, grapefruit and a long sharp bitter finish. Nice

2009 Bottle @ Brewpub.

    Aroma has a big fruity almost cider-like nose, amber, pours a tiny white head. Flavour is again a full on apple rather than wine taste? Medium bodied, very well balanced, and a lovely mouthfeel. A real treat! Thanks for sharing Luc!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 Bottle: Poured a dirty beige color ale with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of Belgian malt with some dry hops and some easily detectable vinous notes. Taste is also a well balanced mix between some vinous notes with dry hops and typical Belgian pale malt. Body is quite full with great carbonation and no signs of the alcohol. Very well done though more tart notes à la  Russian River would have provided more complexity which would have been interesting. (3.6)

2016 ratings. 6 months old bottle shows more complexity and the pinot notes are very well integrated. Lots of complexity and great balance overall.

341 ml bottle via Lubiere (merci!), served almost cold in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Cloudy orange-golden with a modest white head.
  
Aroma:  Certainly different than the original, the initial aroma is slightly vinous and funky tartness, still some leafy hops, but certainly much less, some nice sweet honey and malts, slight esters, certainly lemony, an odd and ephemeral cigar ash aroma, apricot fruitiness, almost a peppery quality; certainly interesting.
  
Palate:  Medium body, fairly sparse effervescence.
  
Flav.:  A nice resinous/pine hope presence, there is certainly a vinous, oaky quality to the beer, the malts are more subdued, the malt/ester fruitiness is nearly gone, replaced by tart wine fruit, some yeast notes; dry with a touch of brightness and fairly solid bitterness, leaving a biscuity malt finish. 

This is definitely an interesting experience.  I was pretty happy with the normal DV, and I dont think that this one tops it.

Pours a cloudy golden color with a thin white head. Solid aroma of yeast, honey, wood, raisins and alcohol, theres not much of a hops aroma. There a warm presence of alcohol in the flavor along some wood, raisins and honey, again, the hops are discreet. The body is light to medium with a slightly vinous texture and gentle carbonation. This is definitely an interesting experiment, but I prefer the original to this version.

Tried a first bottle in St-Jérôme and it was such a velvety, smooth and overall delightful version of that brew I already love that I bought 6 bottles to go, as much as they allowed me to buy...  The white wine flavors are obvious and in perfect harmony.  Another enchanting brew from that beer-wizard.  And, and, and, the employees told me theres an oak-aged Solstice dhiver presently aging and that will soon be available.  Keep up the oak-aging attemps, you magical brewer of my dreams!

Bouteille de 341 ml, au brewpub de Montréal. Arômes de chêne, légère touche de houblon et belles notes vineuses. On devine une légère présence de levure sauvage. Robe dorée et légèrement trouble, effervescence moyenne et légère mousse. Très belle complexité en bouche, on retrouve les caractéristiques de la Dernière Volonté régulière (céréales mielleuses, levure épicée et houblon herbacé et citronné) qui sont ici accompagnées de notes vineuses et de chêne. Finale boisée et sèche et également légèrement amère. Une belle variante dune excellente bière.

341 ml Bottle drank at brewpub in Montreal, January 16, 2010. Foggy blonde, little head. Aroma of pale malt, notes of tart berries and grapes. Taste of dry hops, notes of herbs and softs berries, good bitterness. Other then the aroma, IMO there is no differance between the one and the regular.

***2009 Vintage (bottled Aug. 2009)***

Despite what the label says, the ABV is 7.5% as per JF Gravel of DDC.

Im kind of excited as this is my first local barrel-aged beer.

Poured from a 341ml. bottle.

Appearance: A slightly clear, gold body fills the glass that gets decidedly hazier as i pour the last of the bottle and the yeast mixs in. A thick and insistent head that gradually receds leaving lots of lacing. A good start for sure.

Smell: Citrus & yeast that come out at first followed by some funk & bubblegum. Bananas & cloves are present as well. At first i dont smell the Pinot but later on i get a whiff of wine. Very nice indeed.

Taste: Im struck as to how the Pinot aspect is quite present in the first sips. Has a slight vinegar edge, not unpleasant, with a dose of funk and an overall dryness to it. Definite wood presence also. Some banana flavor mixed in there as well as a spicy clove finish. Though there is a definite Belgian influence, the Pinot is the prime player here.

Mouthfeel: The best feature of this beer IMO. Very low carbonation which makes this beer just glide in my mouth with effortless ease. Though the Pinot is strong, i find the body quite literally amazing. So very good.

Drinkability: Drinks quite well with an ABV that is not easily perceptible in the taste. Though the strength of the barrel-aged Pinot took me some getting used to, i grew accustomed to it and ended up loving the taste.

Overall: While drinking this beer, i could sense that this was an experiment but i believe that they pulled it off quite well. Too bad not many people will get a chance to try it but worth the effort to acquire IMO.

341ml bottle from DDC in St-Jerôme. Pours clear amber with a small head. Head goes away fast A light veil of foam stays on and extensive lacing remains on the glass walls. Nose is yeasty with a light touch of oak and some hints of tartness/funk. Some hints of white grapes also with some alcohol. Taste is yeasty and fruity with hints of barrel. Finish is quite warm with hints of oak and yeast. Light bitterness. Carbonation is rather soft but fizzy. Taste has some hints of white grapes also. Really nice brew. Im glad DDC is starting to do stuff like that even if its only in very small quantities and you have to drive up to St-Jerôme to get some !

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Bottle. Nice golden-peach color. Lots of oak age aromas here, lambic-like, something definitely floral, fruit flowers, grapes, fresh butter. Taste is very complex; woody, earthy, some grass and a bit of those winey grapes, light acetic finish. Very nice palate, quite smooth and velvety, rich. Very enjoyable oak-aged beer. 

Rerate: Tried a second bottle and was pretty off with harsh wood and medicinal fruits and herbs.
